comment._content: An Lieutenant Commander with the same name and initials appears in the “Alphabetical List of the Active Officers” in various editions of the Navy List published in the 1930s and 1940s: The Navy List, May 1939, p. B4, and August 1939, p. B4 includes: L Cr E. A. C. Ball, HMS Protector (seniority 15 Nov 34) [HMS Protector was a fast net layer launched in 1936, later converted into a training ship and ice patrol ship] digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=9... digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=9... The Navy List, January 1945, p. B9 includes: L Cr E. A. C. Ball HMS Rame Head (seniority 15 Nov 34) [There was a HMS Rame Head, a Canadian-built merchant ship converted to a Fort Type Fleet Repair Ship, later used as an SBS training ship (finally broken up in 2009), but the reference here may refer to an older vessel or base] digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=9... There is also the mention of an Acting Commander E. A. C. Ball, RN being appointed Naval Officer in Charge of Addu Atoll base [Maldives] in the Admiralty War Diaries, Eastern Fleet, July 1943. www.naval-history.net/xDKWD-EF1943b.htm

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content:
The TNA record (ADM 196/149/370) is handwritten and rather difficult to decipher, but broadly covers the period to the end of 1931.

Basic dates given are:

Date of Birth: 4 June 1904
Entered Service: 15 January 1918
Acting Sub Lieutenant: 15 Sep 1924
Sub Lieutenant: 15 Apr 1925
Lieutenant: 15 Nov 1926

The record includes his stint as a Midshipman from 1922 (e.g. on Benbow and Victory), where he is described as “somewhat highly strung” and “most conscientious – devotes all his time to becoming sufficient [?], rather shy, highly strung – shd. Become good leader if he overcomes this.”

Later, in March 1928, we find: “29.3.28 Death of Stoker Whitfield, Considered to blame in that he took no steps to ensure that he wd be called in event of liberty men returning on board & after accident occurred ½ hour elapsed before he called C.O.”
